data.title: Rappers, sorted by the size of their vocabulary
data.meta_description: The number of unique lyrics used within artistsâ first 35,000 lyrics
data.text:
35,000 words covers 3 to 5 studio albums and EPs. I included mixtapes if the artist was short of the 35,000 words. Quite a few rappers donât have enough official material to be included (for example, Biggie, Chance the Rapper, Queen Latifah, and El-P).

Since the original release, thereâs now a notable trend of fewer unique words among newer artists. This is easier to see in the following chart, where I highlighted each artistâs primary decade, based on album release dates for their vocabulary calculation (the first 35,000 lyrics).

Raw Lyrics Data via John W. Miller

In short, if artists depart from hip-hop song structure, weâd expect their vocabulary to go down in the number of unique words.

That said, the results are still directionally interesting. Of the 150 artists in the dataset, letâs take a look at who is on top.

#1 - Aesop Rock

When I first published this analysis, I excluded Aesop Rock, figuring he was too obscure. The Reddit hip-hop community was in an uproar, claiming that Aesop would absolutely be #1. Sure enough, Aesop Rock is well above every artist in the dataset, and I was obliged to add him to the chart.

#2 - Busdriver

For the most recent update, I pored over requests from readers, and Busdriver was most common on folksâ wishlists. He and Aesop Rock are the only rappers with more than 7,000 unique words in their first 35,000 lyrics.

#4, #5, #7, #10, #15, and #20 - Wu-Tang Clan Ain’t Nuthing Ta F’ Wit

Wu-Tang Clan at #5 is impressive given that 10 members, with vastly different styles, equally contribute lyrics. Add the fact that GZA, Ghostface, Raekwon, and Method Man's solo works are also in the top 20 â notably, GZA is at #4.

#28, #54 - Outkast and E-40

Of course E-40 is in the top 20%; heâs considered to be the inventor of many slang terms. Just a few that heâs been responsible for coining or popularizing: âall good,â âpop ya collar,â âshizzle,â and âyou feel me.â

Outkastâs expansive vocabulary is definitely a function of their style: frequent use of portmanteaus (for example, âATLiens,â âStankoniaâ), southern drawl (for example, ânahmsayin,â âeryâdayâ), and made-up slang (for example, âflawsky-wawskyâ).

#49 and #59 - Busta Rhymes and Twista

Since both rappers are known for their speed, itâs nice to see that their verses are just as lyrically diverse as their peersâ.

So what's all this mean?

io9 writer Robert Gonzalez blew my mind with this point, âOn the Black Album track 'Moment of Clarity,' Jay-Z contrasts his lyricism with that of Common and Talib Kweliâ (both of whom rank higher than him, when it comes to the diversity of their vocabulary):

I dumbed down for my audience to double my dollars

They criticized me for it, yet they all yell âhollaâ

If skills sold, truth be told, Iâd probably be

Lyrically Talib Kweli

Truthfully I wanna rhyme like Common Sense

But I did 5 mil - I ainât been rhyming like Common since

I used a research methodology called token analysis to determine each artistâs vocabulary. Each word is counted once, so pimps, pimp, pimping, and pimpin are four unique words. To avoid issues with apostrophes (e.g., pimpinâ vs. pimpin), theyâre removed from the dataset. It still isnât perfect. Hip hop is full of slang that is hard to transcribe (e.g., shorty vs. shawty), compound words (e.g., king shit), featured vocalists, and repetitive choruses.

If you’re looking for more quantitative analysis of hip hop, check out Tahir Hemphill’s many foundational projects (and whose work initially inspired this analysis) and Martin Conner’s Rap Analysis.

Vocabulary count data is available here.

Notable artists currently excluded, under the 35,000 threshold: Cardi B, Dej Loaf, Princess Nokia, Rae Sremmurd, Dreezy, Remy Ma, Dej Loaf, Da Brat, Princess Nokia, Queen Latifah, Azealia Banks, Nav, Dreezy, Earl Sweatshirt, Eyedea, Jay Electronica, Pharoahe Monch, Pusha T, Saba, Waka Floka Flame, XXXTentacion.
